As young as the year is, 2021 has a lot of potential.

That “fresh-start” feeling at the beginning of every year may be short lived for some, but it can give us the boost we need to start something new, including this blog!

You may be a parent, an educator, or simply a member of our local community in search of new ideas, but regardless the reason, we’re happy to have you with us and we look forward to hearing from you! (We welcome your comments below!) Our Little Sprouts blog will be a place where we share helpful insights and a handful of topics related to childcare and our community.

Before fully embarking on our journey into 2021, we’d like to share a few things our little ones have taught us this past year, what we’ve decided to keep and toss from 2020, and how to get ready for new memories!Read MoreDECEMBER 9, 2020

2. Imitate the “Joy-Finding-Experts”
Despite unexpected changes and shifts, another thing we admire about children is their ability to find joy, and not just when they choose to, but as it comes:

  • The giant leaf they found outside? Amazing!
  • A cotton-candy sunset? Sweet.
  • The fairy drawing that looks more like a shark? Even better.

These little humans enjoy the little things, and that alone gives us joy-not to mention the inspiration to keep our own imaginations alive and well.

3. Keep Your Discoveries

Although there are many things we wish we could leave behind in 2020, holding onto what helped us get through is a must. Perhaps this is a special memory you shared during quarantine or a new project or hobby.

Little did we know these “joyful distractions” would become a new facet of our life, helping to loosen the pandemic’s grip on our minds. Going outside more, finding hidden gems in our own neighborhoods, and connecting with friends have become a way of life, keeping us safe and satisfied.

All of this has kept the momentum going and its good practice for what’s to come, with or without a pandemic in the picture.

Before You Go…

Though 2020 felt like a class we didn’t intend to sign up for, we definitely learned some important lessons that we can apply now and in the future!

We can do our best to imitate the way children grow no matter the circumstances, find daily reasons for joy, and recall the good memories with a healthy anticipation for new ones.‘Till we meet again, here’s a few things to munch on:

  • What things did you gain in the past year that you’re bringing into 2021?
  • What do you admire most about children during difficult times?
  • What good memories will you hold onto?
